data.proxyObjectName: individually wrapped rectangular cracker snack in clear red-accented plastic packaging
data.utilizationMethod: Lay the wrapped cracker flat on the table. Strike the centre of the biscuit through the plastic. The hard, brittle cracker resists until its internal structure fractures; the instant it snaps there’s a loud crack and the hammer head sinks a few millimetres into the softened crumbs, producing a very clear breakthrough moment without needing to open the packaging.

data.proxyObjectName: blue Pilot Vboard Master whiteboard eraser box
data.utilizationMethod: Stand the small cardboard box on one short end like a miniature log. Chop down into the top panel. The stiff cardboard offers an initial firm stop; keep pressing and the box buckles, then topples flat, removing resistance and producing a tangible ‘break’ that aligns with the visual of firewood splitting.

Grip the narrow top knob (about 1.5–2 cm diameter) as the handle and let the heavier main cylinder hang below and forward. The dense 50 g mass gives clear inertia, closely imitating the sensation of a filled mug hanging from a small rod handle.

data.proxyObjectName: green plush turtle shell with white rim
data.utilizationMethod: Grip the plush shell by squeezing a section of the white rim so the large padded mass hangs outward. The soft, substantial volume provides pronounced inertia that lags at swing start and follows through heavily, giving a cushioned but convincing sensation of a weighted axe head.

data.proxyObjectName: black and silver telescoping selfie stick with phone clamp
data.utilizationMethod: Keep the pole retracted and grip the rubber handle; the metal phone clamp on the opposite end delivers pronounced forward weight. This configuration closely mimics an actual hammer: cylindrical grip, clear head-heavy balance, and sufficient length for wrist-plus-elbow swings.

Hold the inner cardboard core at one edge with a firm grip, allowing the bulk of the roll to extend forward. The cylindrical handle is firm while the paper layers add moderate weight, creating front-loaded inertia. As you swing, sheets flutter and create air resistance, approximating the drag the sickle experiences before breaking through a stem.
